So some of the properties of a normal distribution can be the mean, median and mode of a normal

For example, if let's say we have a distribution of 1000 employees salary and the mean is

So that is all about the probability distributions. Now let's go ahead and understand
standard central limit theorem. So a central limit theorem states that if we take several random
samples from a population that has a finite variance the mean of the samples will form a normal
distribution. Now this is a little trick here we are taking let's say we have a population which
has 10,000 observations. Now we are taking 1000 sample samples. Let's say we are taking 20 samples
or 50 samples from that particular population being 1000 observations each.
The mean of those 1000 observations for each of the sample if we plot them on a graph it will
create a normal distribution that is what the central limit theorem says. So there are a few
limitations or we can say assumptions that we have today. So the sample should not exceed 10%
of the population. So let's say the population has 1000 observations the samples will only have 100
or less than 100. And sample itself or the population might not be normally distributed.
So that is also there it does not necessarily mean that your population is already normally
distributed and then the mean of the samples will be distributed when we calculate the sample means.
That is also not there. Now to understand this the central limit theorem you can plot the same
